\makecvtitle{}{}

\section{Industry Experience}

\cventry{2021 -- 22}{Engineer Manager, Data Science}{Jampp}{Remote}{}{I defined development priorities for my team alongside Tech and
Product managers. I coordinated the migration from in-house GLMs estimators
to LightGBM. We professionalized the team, by implementing agile methodologies,
documenting internal libraries and setting reproducibility standards
for our analysis. I wrote the first career ladder, updated the technical
exams and grew the team from 7 to 12 people.}

\cventry{2019 -- 20}{Senior Data Scientist}{Jampp}{Buenos Aires}{}{I assisted in the development of the income optimization engine
for our Real Time Bidding (RTB) service. We presented the results
in the \href{https://www.adkdd.org/Papers/Optimal-bidding\%3A-a-dual-approach/2019}{2019 KDD}.
Our team was responsible for the system predicting ads' conversion
rates (win rate, CTR, CVR). We trained cheaply on several billions
observations with an in-house, online SGD algo, and processed 1M+
auctions per seconds, using strongly regularised GLMs.}

\cventry{2016 -- 19}{Expert Data Analysis Advisor}{Jefatura de Gabinete de Ministros}{BA}{}{Our team implemented an end-to-end business intelligence system
to integrate data from key systems of the National Public Administration
(e.g. Budget, Payroll, Public Policies). I worked in defining the
data model definition and developing ETLs, apart from advising the
Justice and Economy ministries on how to define their OKRs within
the system.}

\cventry{2013 -- 16}{Business Analyst}{NASCAR Members Club}{Buenos Aires \& Charlotte, NC}{}{I automated all operative reports for Marketing and Logistics.
I designed and executed a multiple hypothesis test in order to choose
a subscription plan to minimise subscribers' churn. I reduced credit
card chargebacks significantly with a logistic model trained on our
members' past purchase history.}

\section{Teaching Experience}

\cventry{$2^{\text{nd}}$ sem. 2021}{External Professor}{Facultad de Cs. Exactas y Naturales, Facultad de Ingeniería, UBA}{Buenos Aires}{Virtual}{I taught ``Machine Learning in Graphs'', with Prof. Martín
Elías Costa, Ph.D.\emph{ }Video lectures available at \href{https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PL1WsZAYeCpYUA-k5Ry5O803GpipEnoFQk}{Youtube},
exercise guides and didactic materials at \href{https://github.com/fcen-amateur/aa-en-grafos}{GitHub}.}

\cventry{2012 -- 17}{Mathematical Olympiad Coach}{Colegio Boston, Escuela Intl. New Model y Colegio Bayard}{Buenos Aires}{}{Middle \& High School levels.}

\pagebreak{}

\section{Academic Record}

\cventry{2017 -- 21}{MSc in Mathematical Statistics}{Instituto del Cálculo, FCEyN, UBA}{}{}{GPA 10.0}

\cventry{Thesis}{Fermat Distance in Kernel Density Estimators}{}{}{in progress}{ I propose to train a KDE classifier with a data-learned distance
- Fermat's Distance - instead of the customary euclidean distance
in order to learn not only the sample density, but also its geometry
(i.e. its supporting Riemmannian manifold). I evaluate the classifier
against related algorithms such as Naive Bayes, and state-of-the art
techniques such as GBTs and NNs. Director: Pablo Groisman, Ph.D. }

\cventry{2009 -- 14}{Licenciatura (\textasciitilde MSc) en Economía}{Facultad de Cs. Económicas, UBA}{}{}{GPA 8.94\emph{. }I graduated \emph{magna cum laude} as class valedictorian.}

\cventry{Thesis}{The limits of electoral predictability}{}{}{}{Using open data from 2013 legislative elections, I Usando datos
abiertos de las elecciones legislativas nacionales del 2013, primero
estimé el mínimo error posible en la predicción del resultado del
comicio, en función del tamaño muestral; luego, analicé la veracidad
de afirmaciones periodísticas contemporáneas. Públicamente disponible
en GitHub {[}\href{https://github.com/capitantoto/tesis_mesis}{link}{]}.
Director: Silvia Vietri, Ph.D. Grade: 10.0. }

every course I've given or taken at FCEyN, fostering programming practices
in the academic community.}

metadata, is part of the Inter-American Development Bank ``Code for
Development'' FOSS program. }

from Stanford at Coursera, teaching to code fundamental machine learning
algorithms from scratch.}
